autumn.lang

Interface StaticFunctor

  • All Superinterfaces:
    Functor, TypedFunctor
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractStaticFunctor, FileProcessor, Predicate

    public interface StaticFunctor
extends TypedFunctor
    This interface is the supertype of statically defined functor types.

    A class that implements this interface should also provide a single invoke(*) method. The method's parameters are the parameters to the functor. The return-type of the method is the return-type of the functor. For example, imagine a functor that takes an int parameter and returns a double. Then, the class should provide an invoke(int) : double.

    A class that implements this interface should provide a single constructor. The constructor should take a Functor as its only parameter. The functor will become the inner() functor.

    The parameterTypes() method and the returnType() method should be implemented independently of the inner() functor. In other words, those methods should return immutable lists that were created directly by the implementor.

    The apply(ArgumentStack) method simply invokes the apply(ArgumentStack) method of the inner() functor.

    • Method Summary

      Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void apply(ArgumentStack stack)
      This method performs an invocation of this function object.
      Functor inner()
      This method retrieves the functor that is wrapped by this object.
      java.util.List<java.lang.Class> parameterTypes()
      This method retrieves the types of the functor's formal-parameters.
      java.lang.Class returnType()
      This method retrieves the type of the value that is returned by this functor.

      • apply

        void apply(ArgumentStack stack)
           throws java.lang.Throwable
        This method performs an invocation of this function object.

        Programmers should not call this method directly. Instead, for convenience, call this method indirectly via (F::apply List).

        Calling Convention from top to bottom (n >= 0):

        1. argument[n]
        2. argument[.]
        3. argument[2]
        4. argument[1]
        5. argument[0]

        The argument stack will be cleared and then the result will be pushed onto it. If the functor does not return a value, then the stack will remain empty.

        Specified by:
        apply in interface Functor
        Parameters:
        stack - is a stack containing the arguments being passed to this functor.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Throwable - in order to propagate exceptions thrown by the functor.
